comments:
3.0M9 + HEAD

- enable "close editors automatically"
- set "n. of open editors" to 1
- quickly switch between CUs
-> the old reconciling thread may still run while the new one is launched

I found IOOBs and NPEs while running in the semantic highlighting reconciling
listener which are likely caused by this.

Bug 34800 discusses a similar problem.
please attach the stack traces for those exceptions

They didn't make it to the log. However, I was able to reproduce the following
quite regularly with the scenario from bug 62861. Note that bug 61508 may hide
this, my runtime - from which this exception is - has a fix for this bug.

From looking at PositionCollector#visit(SimpleName), it's quite clear that the
NPE can only happen if either the simple name is null from the beginning or
SemanticToken#clear() has been called by a different thread.

Similarly, the AIOOB can only happen if another thread called
SemanticHighlightingReconciler#stopReconcilingPositions().

When the editor input is changed, the old reconciler is uninstalled and a new
one installed. Even after uninstalling, the old reconciler may be still
processing a dirty region.

Since the two reconcilers are fully independent objects, this is not a problem.
The only object that is shared between the two reconcilers is the viewer or editor.

JavaReconcilingStrategy.reconcile() refers to the editor to get its input,
however, that input may already have changed when the method is invoked.

The produced AST (based on the new CU already) is then propagated to the
JavaEditor and its IJavaReconcilerListeners, notably the ASTProvider,
OverrideIndicatorManager and SemanticHighlightingReconciler.

When the editor input is switched from oldCU to newCU, JavaReconcilingStrategy
may send out:

- an AST for oldCU to the editor already displaying newCU
- an AST for newCU interleaving with the new reconciler

Neither OverrideIndicatorManager nor SemanticHighlightingReconciler are
threadsafe. They do expect being called from a separate thread than the UI
thread, but not from multiple threads.

Sending the "reconciled" message from JavaReconcilingStrategy should be
synchronized with the editor input change. We must not update editor (or viewer)
structures from two different reconcilers.

In order to solve this, we need to synchronize the two reconcilers somewhere on
the shared resource 'editor'.

We cannot simply wait for the old reconciler to finish when changing editor
input: the old reconciler will update the editor while its UI thread is blocked,
which may be deadlock territory.

fixed temporarily by synchronizing on a mutex provided by CompilationUnitEditor.
This assures that at most one reconciler is active on the editor.

I filed bug 66176 to track this issue after 3.0
verified in I200406110010 through code inspection
